headline: Ruben Amorim issues worrying Bruno Fernandes injury update to compound Man Utd woes
body: Bruno Fernandes is facing an injury lay-off after title-chasing Aston Villa made it 10 straight wins. Manchester United captain Fernandes went off at half-time which is a huge worry for Ruben Amorim as they suffered a rare defeat at Villa Park.
Incredibly, it was only Villa's second win in 27 Premier League home games against United as Morgan Rogers' spectacular double put Unai Emery's men back to within three points of leaders Arsenal.

But it was a bad day for United with Amorim now concerned that Fernandes - who has missed just 17 games in five years since arriving in 2020 - will be out while he also expects Kobbie Mainoo to miss the Boxing Day fixture with Newcastle United.

United boss Amorim, who said Mainoo missed the Villa game after suffering a calf injury, added: "It's a soft tissue, I think he's going to lose some games, I don't know for sure. Let's see. I don't know. I don't what to talk about matters you can't control.
"He is a guy who is always fit, so he might recover quite well. I think Kobbie Mainoo is out, Bruno is out. We will see. No excuses, we need to win the next game and we will try to win the next game.

The Red Devils, who are already without Noussair Mazraoui, Amad and Bryan Mbeumo because of AFCON, play Newcastle at home before hosting Wolves four days later. Their first game of 2026 is away to Leeds.
Amorim went on to address United's wider injury problems, having called on two academy graduates for their debuts in the second half. "It is really strange," the Red Devils boss explained.

"During this year, especially at this time, we have so many problems, but we have to cope with that. I think [Jack] Fletcher did his first game, so that is good news, [Shea] Lacey the same, so we will try to find solutions and go for the next game.

"I am a manager for six years and even Sporting [Lisbon] is all about the academy, so it's about the history. Every manager wants to bring players through from the academy and not spend money because this gives value to the manager.

"I just want to win and want to be certain that the players that come in from the academy are not going to suffer too much. I'm just trying to help the club, it doesn't matter if it's from the academy or abroad."

headline: opinionAston Villa show Man Utd what they're missing as Morgan Rogers sends England message
body: Unai Emery tore off his coat, swirled it above his head and then threw it away in sheer delight. Villa Park was alive, the noise was deafening as the home fans stood together to cheer another unforgettable moment from Morgan Rogers.
There have been a few this season but his first of two pieces of magic in one game underlines why Emery’s Aston Villa are in the thick of this title race. No wonder Emery was excited.

It is now 10 straight wins in all competitions for Villa and, even more incredibly, it was only their second win over United in 27 Premier League games at Villa Park. They are a team blitzing records.

It also showed why England boss Thomas Tuchel rates Rogers so highly and the Villa forward is making a very strong case to start the World Cup even ahead of his boyhood pal Jude Bellingham. Rogers was exceptional and, most importantly, he stepped up when Villa needed him most because they were not at their best and could count themselves rather fortunate to win.

Manchester United played well in large parts of the game but they lacked the game-changing, defining moments of brilliance which are supposed to be in the club’s DNA. Matheus Cunha drew them level with a brilliant, clinical finish but then missed an absolute sitter to get United a second equaliser.

Even more worryingly, Bruno Fernandes went off at half-time after stretching out his leg and if he is out for any time then you fear for a United team already missing Bryan Mbeumo and Amad who are away on AFCON duty. You might have thought it could be a chance for Kobbie Mainoo but he missed the trip to Villa Park because of a calf injury.

A cynic might be suspicious that his absence came just a few days after his brother wore a “Free Kobbie Mainoo” T-shirt in protest at his continued absence from the United starting line-up. But surely no manager would cut off their nose to spite their face.
Ruben Amorim also needs every bit of help he can get. Another blank for £74m striker Benjamin Sesko who has yet to get going at Old Trafford.

Amorim cut a frustrated figure as he threw on youngsters Shea Lacey and also Jack Fletcher - son of ex-United midfielder Darren who is still on the staff - for his senior debut. But even as Villa tired, United just could not find a way back.
Rogers reigned supreme again as he just looks unstoppable right now. For club and country.
Is Morgan Rogers currently the best player in the Premier League? Let us know your pick in the comments section.

His first goal lit up the whole game because after Villa’s fast start, it had faded away. Then Rogers struck. John McGinn sent over a long ball, Rogers’ heavy touch nearly let it run out of play but he showed all his pace and determination to keep it in.

Rogers then darted in from the left wing, cut inside and then curled a sensational shot into the top corner to give Villa the lead on 45 minutes. But, within three minutes and deep into first half injury time, United levelled.
Matty Cash found himself under pressure, Patrick Dorgu got a touch to Cunha who steadied himself and then made a smart finish into the far corner. Villa were ahead again after 57 minutes.

Youri Tielemans put the ball across, Ollie Watkins could not control it and then Rogers latched on and curled another brilliant shot into the far corner. Another Christmas cracker from Rogers. Sheer brilliance. Somehow Cunha headed wide from Dorgu’s cross to level again and Villa held on.

United will play worse and win. This was not a day for an Amorim crisis but it was a game which highlighted the reliance on Fernandes, a growing list of absences and also Sesko’s continual struggles. In contrast, after Villa’s worst start in 28 years which left them in utter disarray, they now have an incredible and wonderful momentum.

headline: Morgan Rogers downs toothless Man Utd as Aston Villa's streak continues - 5 talking points
body: Morgan Rogers was the star of the show as Aston Villa beat Manchester United 2-1 at Villa Park. The victory makes it 10 in a row for Unai Emery's side, who are keeping pace with Arsenal and Manchester City at the top.

A special strike from Rogers opened the scoring on the brink of half-time. But it was quickly cancelled out by Matheus Cunha in rather fortuitous circumstances after an early Christmas present from Matty Cash.

With Bruno Fernandes going off injured at the interval, United were weakened and Rogers took advantage by scoring his and Villa's second goal before the hour mark. Ruben Amorim's toothless attack were unable to draw level and saw their four-game unbeaten run come to an end.
Here are five talking points from Villa Park.

With Casemiro suspended, there was a good chance that Kobbie Mainoo would finally start his first Premier League game of the season. But when team news was confirmed, the 20-year-old was conspicuous by his absence.

As it turns out, Mainoo injured his calf during training on Saturday and it wasn't some form of punishment by Amorim. A storm erupted this week after Mainoo's half-brother wore a t-shirt to Monday's 4-4 draw with Bournemouth emblazoned with the text 'Free Kobbie Mainoo'.
Who else to open the scoring? Rogers has now scored six goals in his last six league games since the November international break.

His luscious effort to break the deadlock against the run of play was the pick of the bunch, too. Collecting the ball on the left flank, Rogers glided inside and took on Leny Yoro before unleashing a curling strike into Senne Lammens' top-right corner.
United's goalkeeper didn't even move. For Rogers' second, he beat Yoro again and produced a similar albeit less spectacular strike which Lammens had no chance of stopping.
It'll take something unwelcome or someone special for Rogers not to be starting for England at the World Cup. Cole Palmer and Jude Bellingham have their work cut out.
United probably owe Cash a Christmas card. In May, his weak backpass led to Emi Martinez's sending off in a moment that changed the course of the teams' last meeting, a 2-0 win for the Red Devils.
This time, the Poland international dawdled on the ball and was caught by the pressing of Patrick Dorgu. The ball fell kindly to Cunha, whose first-time finish ripped past Martinez.

United, who'd dominated parts of the first half, were level just three minutes after conceding. But there was a concern, with Bruno Fernandes clutching his hamstring on multiple occasions before the break.

It's not often you see Fernandes nursing an injury and even rarer to see him being substituted because of one. But a hamstring problem forced United's captain off at half-time and he was replaced by Lisandro Martinez, brought on to play in an unconventional midfield role.

The Red Devils had less of a goal threat with the enforced changed, perhaps a sign of things to come. With the always hectic festive period ahead, and with both Bryan Mbeumo and Amad at the Africa Cup of Nations, Fernandes' prolonged absence would be sorely felt.

A lot has been said about the Red Devils' academy in recent weeks, much of it by Amorim. But the United manager put his faith in youth by firstly subbing on Jack Fletcher, the son of ex-United star Darren.
There was another debut soon after, as the highly rated Shae Lacey entered proceedings in the closing stages. But there were no dream debuts, as Villa saw out the win.

headline: Man Utd handed Bruno Fernandes injury blow as hobbling star forced off
body: Bruno Fernandes has handed Manchester United an injury blow during his side's game at Aston Villa on Sunday, coming off with a hamstring complaint.

Ruben Amorim's side were in desperate need of a result heading into Sunday's clash at Villa Park, not least to keep the pace with top four rivals Liverpool and Chelsea. A win in the Midlands would take them level on 29 points, while a draw would leave them two points adrift.
It was a lively start to the game, with Villa close to scoring through Morgan Rogers on occasion. United also had chances through Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko.

The deadlock was eventually broken on the brink of half-time as Rogers did get his goal, cutting inside and firing a rocket into the net from just inside the box. But Villa's lead was short-lived as United got back on level terms almost instantly as Matty Cash was dispossessed close to the United goal and Cunha found the far corner.

It can be argued the scoreline was the least of United's concerns, however, as captain Fernandes appeared to pull up late in the first-half. He was able to play on until the whistle, but was clearly in some discomfort as the players made their way to the dressing room.

Therefore, it was no surprise to see Amorim make a change at the break. There were limited options on the bench, with both Joshua Zirkzee and Lisandro Martinez the only two senior outfield players available.

It was Martinez who got the nod, with Fernandes then pictured with his coat on making his way back to the bench before kick-off. It was a bitter flow for the Red Devils as their captain has arguably been one of their most consistent performers this term.

Interestingly, pundit and former United defender Gary Neville was a little surprised by Amorim's decision to take a more defensive approach with his change. Speaking on commentary, he questioned why it was Martinez instead of Zirkzee who was called upon for the second 45 minutes.
"I am surprised because I thought Zirkzee would come on just because he is closer to Bruno's position," Neville argued. "I am quite surprised.

"Zirkzee doesn't look like he is too happy with it either, but you can see there now Martinez has gone in there alongside (Manuel) Ugarte in central midfield. He played there for Ajax a few times as well, United now have a back five and Ugarte and Martinez in front.
"It was a real shock to see Bruno pull up with his hamstring because he is ever present and hardly misses a game."

It took a little over ten minutes into the second half, but Villa were able to restore their lead to make it 2-1. Rogers, once again, found the net for the hosts with another curled effort into the far corner.

headline: Ozzy Osbourne's grandson is Aston Villa mascot for Man Utd clash in emotional moment
body: The grandson of Black Sabbath legend and Aston Villa fan Ozzy Osbourne was among the mascots as the club took on Manchester United in the Premier League on Sunday. Sidney, the son of Ozzy's daughter Kelly, was carried out by Villa captain John McGinn before the match.
Villa paid tribute to Ozzy back in August after the rock star died at the age of 76. He played his final gig at their Villa Park stadium back in July, just weeks before his death.

Following Osbourne's death, Villa paid a tribute of their own. "Aston Villa Football Club is saddened to learn that world-renowned rockstar and Villan, Ozzy Osbourne has passed away," a statement from the club read at the time.

"Growing up in Aston, not far from Villa Park, Ozzy always held a special connection to the club and the community he came from. The thoughts of everyone at Aston Villa are with his wife Sharon, his family, friends, and countless fans at this extremely difficult time. Rest in peace, Ozzy."
Ozzy's daughter Kelly got engaged to partner Sid Wilson before her father's final show. The couple were seen on the pitch with youngster Sidney ahead of kick-off in Sunday's match against United.
Ozzy's final Villa Park show saw him joined by original members of Black Sabbath for a concert dubbed 'back to the beginning'. At the time, he spoke about the significance of the event.

"It’s my final encore; it’s my chance to say thank you to my fans for always supporting me and being there for me. I couldn’t have done my final show anywhere else. I had to go back to the beginning," he said.

On the pitch, Villa hosted United knowing three points would keep their title charge alive. They had won their last two matches in dramatic fashion, scoring a last-gasp winner to beat Arsenal before coming from behind for a 3-2 victory at West Ham.

"Villa are definitely in the title race for me," former Villa and United striker Dion Dublin told Match of the Day. "I think in Unai Emery they have a manager who knows how to maintain performance levels and keep them firing."

"The elite teams always stay humble. I also think it is a mindset thing, we have to stay strong mentally, especially if you are on this run. We know it can stop at any time. The way we are going and the players that we have, I believe that we can go very far if we keep doing what we're doing and working hard."

headline: Nemanja Matic names which of his four Man Utd managers deserved more time at Old Trafford
body: Former Manchester United midfielder Nemanja Matic played under four different managers during his Old Trafford spell. Jose Mourinho brought him to Old Trafford, but it was the Portuguese's successor Ole Gunnar Solskjaer who Matic believes was dismissed too early.

Solskjaer replaced Mourinho in December 2019, initially on an interim basis before being appointed permanently. He was the second United boss of Matic's five years at Old Trafford, eventually losing his job in 2021

Michael Carrick and Ralf Rangnick spent time in interim charge after Solskjaer's dismissal, which came after a 4-1 loss at Watford left United seventh in the Premier League. Reflecting on the Norwegian's stint four years later, though, Matic argued United pulled the trigger too soon.
“We finished second and third under him. There was an atmosphere in the team that we weren’t happy finishing second, but when you see the results now, we did amazingly," Matic told FourFourTwo
“I think Ole deserved more time – and when I say Ole, I also want to mention his staff, like Michael Carrick and Kieran McKenna. They were going the right way to bring United back.

“Of course, they made the decision to sack Ole based on his final couple of results, but he was an amazing person with the right profile for the club. He and his assistants understood football – training was perfect and had every little detail ready for us."

Matic praised Solskjaer, in part for how he was able to keep players on board even when they weren't playing regularly. The Serbian started just four of United's 12 league games in his final season, but recognised the manager was someone who knew the club.

Matic would go on to leave Old Trafford in the summer of 2022, linking back up with Mourinho at Roma. He then spent time in France, playing for Rennes and Lyon, and is now back in Italy with Sassuolo.

Solskjaer took time out after leaving United, eventually ending his exile from management when he took over at Besiktas midway through the 2024/25 season. He was dismissed by the Turkish club in August, though, and spoke in November about a potential return to the dugout.

"I'm open, it's not like I'm desperate to be back but England, I love living here, I think so," he told Stick to Football. "My kids ask me mid-Championship and up, but I’m a football man. Is it Norway? Sweden? It’s about working with people. When I played Football Manager and Championship Manager, I like to defy the odds."

headline: Bruno Fernandes' Man Utd release clause bombshell emerges just before Aston Villa clash
body: Manchester United's skipper Bruno Fernandes reportedly has a release clause in his contract that is only applicable to clubs outside the Premier League. Since joining from Sporting in January 2020 for just under £50million, the Portuguese midfielder has become a key player for the Red Devils.

He was appointed captain by ex-manager Erik ten Hag in 2023 and has since racked up over 300 appearances for the club. Under the guidance of Ruben Amorim this season, Fernandes has netted five goals and provided seven assists in his 17 outings across all competitions.
His importance to the team is undeniable, but there was a chance he might not have been at Old Trafford this season if certain members of United's top brass had their way last summer.

Earlier this month, Fernandes dropped a bombshell, revealing that some were trying to push him out of the club during the previous transfer window after a hefty offer came in from Saudi Pro League side Al-Hilal.
Despite the prospect of a significant salary increase, Fernandes chose to stay at Old Trafford, with Amorim also keen to retain him, despite apparent opposition from higher up.
"The club wanted me to go, I have that in my head," he recently confessed to Canal 11. "I told the directors this, but I think they didn't have the courage to make that decision.

"I decided to stay, also because of family reasons, but because I genuinely like the club. The conversation with the manager also made me stay. But, from the club's side, I felt a bit like, 'if you leave, it's not so bad for us.' It hurts me a lot.
"More than hurting, it makes me sad because I'm a player they have nothing to criticise about. I'm always available, I always play, good or bad.
"I give my all. Then you see things around you, players who don't value the club as much and don't defend the club as much... that makes you sad."
Following the interview, which has once again cast doubt over Fernandes' future at Old Trafford, it has now come to light that the midfielder may have an exit clause written into his deal.

According to journalist Fabrizio Romano, the clause can only be activated by clubs outside England. "There is a release clause in the contract of Bruno Fernandes," Romano revealed in his latest YouTube video.
"And the clause is not valid for Premier League clubs. It's only for clubs abroad. It is slightly over €60million (£52.5m). So, nothing is imminent.
"Nothing is happening. For the summer transfer window, I would keep an eye on the interest from Saudi because I think from Saudi, they can return for Bruno Fernandes.
"Then it's going to be up to Bruno, up to Man Utd again. Let's see what's going to happen before or after the World Cup."
Meanwhile, United are gearing up for Sunday's Premier League clash against Aston Villa. A triumph in the Midlands will bring them on par with Liverpool and Chelsea, each holding 29 points.

headline: How Man Utd could line up if Ruben Amorim lands three dream January targets
body: Ruben Amorim has not ruled out January transfers for Manchester United and only wants players who can strengthen his team even after Amad, Bryan Mbeumo and Noussair Mazraoui return from AFCON. That is not always a simple task, but it could help the Portuguese coach kick on this season.

United could go into Christmas in fifth place with a victory over Aston Villa, and new signings could offer a timely boost for Amorim, having already strengthened his squad in the summer with Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko. Perhaps other areas now need attention.
"We'll see," Amorim said when asked if money was available for the transfer window. "The only thing we know is that we only would try to bring players that we think are going to be the future.

"It's not going to be to save something in this moment, to cope with the losses of three players for AFCON. "It’s not going to be like that, even if we try to bring one player, maybe it's not the position that we need more.
"We will try to bring now – and in the end of the season – players that are perfect for our future. I don't know what is going to happen, but it's possible that we can do something."
Antoine Semenyo may be top of the agenda, given the opportunity his £65million release clause provides. The Bournemouth star favours a move to Liverpool, but already met Amorim last summer.

The Portuguese coach is interested in fielding Semenyo as a wingback should he arrive and is said to be unconvinced by his current options. That could see an aggressive set of wingbacks in Amad and Semenyo, when the United boss returns to his favoured formation.

The duo would flank a back three of Leny Yoro , Mathhijs de Ligt and Lisandro Martinez, who would play in front of Senne Lammens. Luke Shaw would be a stiff contender for a spot, but Martinez's passing may give him an edge.
United's midfield could see further additions, with the centre of midfield a priority area for the club. The Guardian reports that Ruben Neves is an option as his contract in Saudi Arabia winds down.

Neves, 28, would cost in the region £20m but could bring significant wage demands after commanding £350,000-a-week. Conor Gallagher could prove to be an alternative option, while it is claimed United are interested in Bournemouth ace Tyler Adams.

Neves would be a strong candidate to start alongside Bruno Fernandes and to keep possession ticking. Tyler Adams may offer more robustness, but is out injured currently, and a second midfield addition may only open the possibility of Old Trafford exits.
A fron three was decided by United's significant summer business. Mbeumo and Cunha will provide plenty of support for Sesko if he can keep Mason Mount of the side.
Possible United lineup: Lammens; Yoro, De Ligt, Martinez; Amad, Neves, Fernandes, Semenyo; Mbeumo, Sesko, Cunha.

headline: Man Utd target Karim Adeyemi embroiled in fresh row after saying yes to Arsenal transfer
body: Germany star Karim Adeyemi will be hit with a fine by Borussia Dortmund following his reaction to being substituted against Borussia Monchengladbach on Friday. The 23-year-old has been linked with a Premier League switch, making it clear he favours Arsenal over Manchester United, but for now remains at Signal Iduna Park

Controversy has followed Adeyemi around of late. The forward, who is represented by Jorge Mendes, recently issued an apology after being fined €450,000 due to being in possession of two illegal weapons (a knuckeduster and a taser), claiming they arrived in a ‘mystery box’ he ordered online.

Adeyemi has six goals and three assists to his name this season, and has either started or come off the bench in every one of Dortmund's Bundesliga games. He lasted an hour against Gladbach on Friday but appeared none too happy about being withdrawn by manager Niko Kovac.

Sporting director Sebastian Kehl intervened when Adeyemi attempted to walk straight down the tunnel. Speaking to Sky Germany after the game (via Yahoo), Kehl explained the situation in more detail while confirming a fine was incoming.

“I told him: He’s not going to the locker room, he’s sitting there,“ Kehl said. ”The substitution was totally justified. Karim didn’t play well. He will be punished for it. I don’t want to see that reaction and neither does the coach or anyone else. It’s not right, and Karim knows that too.
“We’ve discussed this issue intensively with the team in recent weeks. If a player is unhappy, he can express it in the locker room or in the next day’s training session.“

Kovac, meanwhile, said the substitution was performance-based and might even have happened earlier. "I could have made the substitution at halftime, but I didn’t want to. I wanted to give him another chance,” the Croatian said.

Dortmund led early against Gladbach through Julian Brandt but had to wait until the final minute for Maximilian Beier to make the points safe. It means Kovac's side sit second heading into the winter break, albeit still some way adrift of league leaders Bayern Munich.
“I’m very happy that we won. At the end of the day, it was deserved," Kovac said. "We only allowed Gladbach one dangerous chance and missed one or two really good chances ourselves.

"We started well, but then didn’t do so well in the last 15 minutes of the first half. Gladbach came back a bit then. In the second half, it was an open game. We have to continue to work hard, stay focused, work together with the ball, but also against the ball. Then this team definitely have what it takes to finish in the top four.”

body: Manchester United are set to face Aston Villa this weekend with both teams missing several key players. A victory could see Ruben Amorim's squad move level on points with Chelsea and Liverpool, who currently sit in fourth and fifth place.

Should United manage to avoid defeat, they could achieve a five-game unbeaten run for the second time this Premier League season. Amorim will be hoping his team can maintain their scoring streak, having netted eight goals in their last two matches - a 4-1 triumph over Wolves and a thrilling 4-4 draw against Bournemouth.
However, the United manager will undoubtedly be frustrated by the number of star players unavailable for selection today, due to injuries, international commitments and suspensions.
Unai Emery's Villa, on the other hand, will be looking to keep up with Arsenal and Manchester City after their two title rivals both picked up wins on Saturday.
With this in mind, The Mirror has looked at which players will be missing from both teams ahead of the 4:30pm kick-off.

headline: Man Utd's painful Alejandro Garnacho statement after clear regret claim made
body: Manchester United may have seen Alejandro Garnacho as one of the club's future stars, but the player clearly had other ideas.

Chelsea snapped up Garnacho from United in August for £40 million following a breakdown in his relationship with Red Devils manager Ruben Amorim. Just over a year earlier, in December 2024, United had celebrated Garnacho after the 21-year-old winger was crowned FIFA Puskas Award winner, highlighting the club's deep appreciation for their player.

Despite the affection shown to Garnacho by the Red Devils, it seems the feeling wasn't entirely mutual, with Garnacho showing no remorse about departing the red half of Manchester. The Argentine claimed the award for his spectacular goal against Everton in November 2023, when he executed a remarkable overhead kick.

After the strike was recognised as the finest goal scored anywhere on the planet between August 2023 and August 2024, United made sure to praise their young talent. Their message suggested a lengthy future together lay ahead.

A United statement said: "Congratulations to Alejandro Garnacho, who is the winner of the FIFA Puskas Award for 2024. The Manchester United winger has been recognised for the stunning, acrobatic bicycle kick he netted at Everton in November 2023. Well done to our No. 17, and thanks to all those who supported him. It's a goal that we'll cherish for years to come."

Garnacho, even followed the footsteps of his idol Cristiano Ronaldo to become only the second United player to win the award after the Portuguese superstar, is now donning Chelsea blue. Ronaldo was the first recipient of the award back in 2009 for his long-range goal against FC Porto during the 2008/09 season while playing for United.
A year later, Garnacho has swapped Old Trafford for Stamford Bridge and he's not looking back. The winger candidly admitted that his departure from United wasn't a heart-wrenching affair.

He even suggested that leaving United was a necessary move for his career progression. When asked if he had any regrets, Garnacho simply responded, "No." Probed further about whether he felt any sadness over how his time at United concluded, he reiterated: "No."
He added: "Sometimes in life you need to change things to take a step forward or improve as a player," Garnacho explained. "It was the right moment, and the right club. So it was an easy decision."
Upon joining Chelsea, Garnacho didn't hold back in praising his new club during an interview with the official Chelsea media channel.
"I watched the Club World Cup and to join the world champions is special," he said. "We're the best team in the world! It's amazing to be here and I'm very happy."

During his time at United, Garnacho made 144 appearances, netting 26 goals and providing 22 assists. While he views his move to west London as the best decision for his career, his farewell message to United suggests he still holds some fondness for his former club.

Garnacho, who has netted four goals and provided two assists in 18 appearances for Chelsea, said: "After an unforgettable five years, this special chapter in my life now comes to a close. We have created moments that will stay with me forever, and I'm very grateful for this.

"To the coaches, staff, and my team-mates, thank you for believing in me. Every time I wore the badge, I gave everything I had. I leave proud of what we achieved together and excited for what's to come. Wishing the club nothing but success for the future, while I look forward to giving my all in the next chapter of my career."

headline: Aston Villa star is married to Premier League's 'hottest WAG' and used to play for Man Utd
body: During Victor Lindelof's time at Manchester United, his wife, Maja, was bestowed with the title of 'The Premier League's hottest WAG' - and she frequently caught attention throughout his eight years at Old Trafford.

Despite Lindelof spending considerable time in the Premier League, from 2017, when the Red Devils splashed out £30million to bring the Swedish international from Benfica, it wasn't until 2023 that his wife was first given the notable label.

The artificial intelligence app AttractivenessTest.com determined that Maja boasts an attractiveness rating of 9.7/10. However, despite receiving the accolade, she previously revealed on her blog that she loathes being labelled a 'WAG'.

"I am so sick and tired of people trying to make me smaller," she wrote. "Tired of people not knowing what's important in life. I am an entrepreneur. I have my own company and soon I will start one more. If that is with money or love is none of your business."
As owner of fashion brand lisbonneatelier, Maja has built an impressive career for herself and this year moved from Manchester to the Midlands after her husband joined Aston Villa.

Villa emerged victorious in securing Lindelof's services this summer after interest in him from several clubs. He expressed his excitement on deadline day, telling Villa TV: "Obviously it's massive club, and I was super excited when I heard that the club wanted me.

"I spoke to my wife and we felt it was a good move for us as a family and for me as a player. I'm super, super happy and proud to be part of this football club." Lindelof is expected to take to the field in Villa's home match against Man United on Sunday afternoon, marking his first encounter with his old team since leaving last summer.

After making his first league start in their 3-2 victory over West Ham last weekend, his previous ties with United could be a game-changer, Villa manager Unai Emery suggests. The Spanish boss said: "He has experience and he is a very good professional. He has qualities too.

"He is still being young to play football. We signed him in the last moments of the transfer window, because when we identified that possibility, I wanted in that moment everything that he did last week [vs West Ham].

“In 90 minutes he did everything I expected from him. He was really fantastic. Every day it is easy how we are working because his adaptation is so quick, and everything we need, through his experiences, he can give us.

"He gave us experience before, but maybe the best moment he had until now with us was the match at West Ham. He played a fantastic match. Now, he has shown us his level. He can’t stop now, and he must keep it!
"He is very mature, of course. This is very important. He is responsible too, and he has experiences, and hopefully he can help us a lot for the rest of the season."

headline: Transfer theory issued as Kobbie Mainoo is urged to leave Man Utd
body: Former Manchester United star Nicky Butt believes Ruben Amorim might be paving the way for Kobbie Mainoo to depart his boyhood club. The 20-year-old is yet to make a Premier League start this season, and speculation is mounting that he could head out on loan next month, with Napoli leading the chase for his services.

United manager Amorim has stood by his decision to keep the midfielder on the substitutes' bench, insisting "Kobbie needs to fight for his job". He added that it's "not a bad thing to be on the bench of Manchester United when you are 20 years old."

Once hailed as United's next big thing after breaking through with a string of impressive displays during the 2023/2024 campaign, both Butt and former Premier League manager Sam Allardyce reckon the youngster's days at Old Trafford could be numbered. The duo also believe Mainoo should now seek opportunities elsewhere.

Speaking exclusively on the Footy Accumulators No Tippy Tappy Football podcast, in partnership with BOYLE Sports, Butt suggests that Mainoo has found himself trapped in a damaging cycle where extended spells on the sidelines are hampering his ability to make an impact.

The ex-midfielder believes that Mainoo's lacklustre showings when he does feature only serve to vindicate Amorim's choice to regularly bench the youngster, potentially making it easier to offload the star - whether that's in January or during the summer window.

Amorim has extended an open invitation to Mainoo, stating: "If Mainoo wants to come and talk to me, he can". However, Butt suspects there's a reason why Mainoo hasn't approached the manager about his lack of game time.

Butt said: "Nowadays, every player has a management team behind them to look after him. Why is his management team not telling him to go and talk? It might be a case of, don't go in there because we're leaving in January anyway, so I don't really know the ins and outs of it, but it's just a very sad situation.

"He's a great lad, Kobbie. I've known him since he was around 7 or 8 years of age, he's a great talent. It was only a year ago that he was playing in the Champions League at 18, he's not going to lose his talent overnight."

"Kobbie has played nine games this season, and every single one of them has been as a sub. How can he judge someone off that? When I was at United, I wasn't always starting, I had Keane and Scholes in front of me most of the time, I wasn't always getting game time which is why I left."

He added: "There's nothing worse than being out for five or six games, and then the manager puts you in and says, Go and show me what you've got. Because then you've got no rhythm, it takes you five games to get going, from my own experience.
"So if Kobbie gets put in the next game, for example, I guarantee you he won't play well. Then the manager goes, I told you so."

From a managerial perspective, Allardyce defended Amorim. The 71-year-old feels it's up to Mainoo to seek more game time, but he's concerned that the ongoing saga could dent the young midfielder's confidence and suggested he might need to consider leaving the club.

Allardyce said: "He's right. He's rather busy and doing what he's doing. Mainoo's priorities are to stand out in training and prove to the manager his worth to go back into the team. It's also his responsibility to go and knock on the door and ask why he's not playing, not the other way around.

"When you're managing Man United, you haven't got a minute spare. If he's not going to be in the team on Saturday, because he's already got it in his mind whether he is or he isn't, then Mainoo doesn't take priority. He needs to impress to get a chance to be put back in, and he can't wait too long before he has to leave."

He went on to say: "If you destroy somebody's confidence, it's very difficult for them to come back. He's not destroying his confidence on purpose. Whoever Mainoo has around him outside of the football club has a massive responsibility to keep him on track. The amount of players I've seen just finish their training, get their clothes on, and go home is ridiculous. They don't even try to impress the manager.
"Amorim can't give him four or five games to get back on track, because he hasn't got the time. He needs the results now, or he'll be going next.

"He [Mainoo] needs to get away. It'll be foolish for him to sign a new contract at Man United and be a squad player. You play football because it's a talent you've been given and the dream of so many millions of others that haven't made it, and you've got to go and play football."

headline: Ruben Amorim delivers Man Utd transfer hint amid Antoine Semenyo interest - 'It's possible'
body: Ruben Amorim has hinted that Manchester United could conduct some business in the January transfer window, but warned it would not be to cope with the absences of Amad, Bryan Mbeumo, and Noussair Mazraoui. Instead, the Portuguese's focus is on acquiring players who are 'the future' of the club.

The United boss saw a number of signings arrive in the summer, including Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko. Old Trafford chiefs still have plans to sign a new midfielder after failing to land Carlos Baleba in the summer, with the Brighton star, and Elliot Anderson and Adam Wharton among potential candidates.

Antoine Semenyo has been thrust to the forefront of rumours too, however. The Bournemouth ace has a £65million release clause next month and the Red Devils are set to face competition from Manchester City and Liverpool.

Amorim met Semenyo in London at the end of last season, and it remains to be seen if that could give United a leg up. It has even been touted that the Ghana international is being eyed as a wing-back.

And asked if United have a budget to make signings in January, Amorim did not rule out the prospect of new players in 2026. The 40-year-old only wants additions who can aid his team over a long-term period.
"We'll see," Amorim said. "The only thing we know is that we only would try to bring players that we think are going to be the future.

"It's not going to be to save something in this moment, to cope with the losses of three players for AFCON. "It’s not going to be like that, even if we try to bring one player, maybe it's not the position that we need more.
We will try to bring now – and in the end of the season – players that are perfect for our future. I don't know what is going to happen, but it's possible that we can do something."
Amorim also wants Kobbie Mainoo to stay and fight for his job at United. The midfielder has yet to start a Premier League match this term and has been linked with an exit.
"Kobbie needs to fight for his job. I think that it's not a bad thing to be on the bench of Manchester United when you are 20 years old," Amorim said.
"I remember (Cristiano) Ronaldo was on the bench, (Wayne) Rooney was on the bench sometimes. (Juan Sebastian) Veron was not playing.
"I remember all the history of Manchester United and (there is) nobody this didn't fall (to), so let's continue in trying to avoid the nonsense and the noise."

headline: Ruben Amorim sends blunt message to Kobbie Mainoo over Man Utd future
body: Ruben Amorim has urged Kobbie Mainoo to remain at Manchester United and "fight for his job", pointing to Wayne Rooney and Cristiano Ronaldo as examples of players who endured periods on the bench before cementing their Old Trafford legacies.

The academy product is yet to start a Premier League match this season and could depart on loan in January, with Napoli leading a queue of clubs interested in securing his services. However, Amorim wants the youngster to stay and prove himself rather than seek opportunities elsewhere.

The manager has criticised club legends who've suggested Mainoo should leave and has now delivered a direct message to the 20-year-old, who is frustrated by his limited opportunities and has become something of a rallying point for supporters who are eager to see home-grown talent given more chances.

"Kobbie needs to fight for his job. I think that is not a bad thing to be on the bench of Manchester United when you are 20 years old," Amorim explained. "I remember Ronaldo was on the bench, Rooney was on the bench sometimes. [Juan Sebastian] Veron was not playing.
"I remember all the history of Manchester United and nobody. So let's continue in trying to avoid the nonsense and the noise. I just want to help the team win. To help Kobbie to be a better player."
Amorim made it clear he wasn't trying to make an example of Mainoo by benching him, insisting big names must earn their place at Old Trafford.

Instead, he wants the midfielder to prove him wrong when given the opportunity. Mainoo could be in line for his first league start of the campaign at Aston Villa on Sunday, with Amorim hinting at a tactical shift to a back four that might accommodate him as one of three central midfielders.

Should he get the nod, Amorim encouraged the youngster to channel any frustration into his performance. "I'm not trying to say to Kobbie, 'You are a big player here, let's put him on the bench to show something'," he explained.

"No, no. What I'm saying is the opposite. I'm just not putting Kobbie sometimes because I understand that this is not the right guy to start the game. Maybe the next game, on Sunday, he is going to start.

"If he plays well, he's going to show everyone. 'This guy cannot take me from the team', and I will be so happy, so I don't care. I don't want to show nothing to anyone. I'm just saying that I'm trying to win games and to show to the players that if you do the things right, you will play no matter what the name."

Just a week earlier, Amorim had suggested Mainoo could seek a January loan if he wished. That conversation never materialised, but Mainoo's situation took an intriguing twist on Monday when his half-brother Jordan turned up to the Bournemouth match sporting a T-shirt emblazoned with 'Free Kobbie Mainoo'.
"He's a shy boy, but it's not his responsibility. He's responsible for his acts and his act was to play well in the last game, I'm just focused on that," said Amorim.

"I had the situation in Sporting (Lisbon) that my brother wrote something on the internet, and I have to answer for that. My explanation is that he has his life, he has his opinion, and it's nothing to do with me. So I will do the same with Kobbie."

headline: Man Utd news: Jadon Sancho plan emerges as flop is told to make 'perfect' transfer move
body: Manchester United face the tough task of playing Aston Villa on Sunday without three of their key players. Amad, Bryan Mbeumo and Noussair Mazraoui have all departed for AFCON, leaving Ruben Amorim to contend with life without a trio of first-team stars.

Aston Villa boss Unai Emery insists he is committed to the plan of getting the best out of loanee Jadon Sancho before the season's end. The United winger is currently plying his trade with the Villans and is therefore unavailable this weekend so as to avoid playing against his parent club.

Rumours have been building as the January transfer window nears with talk that Villa may end Sancho's deal early to make room in the squad for a permanent addition. However, Emery is relishing the thought of getting the peak of the England international's career while he is still at the club.

He said: "Jadon is still being young. He has had an amazing career and is now in a moment where he needs help to recover his best performance. I have this challenge with him. He has this challenge with me as well. Of course, he is not playing all the minutes I think he has to.

"But in the second part of the season, I believe in him. He is really being demanding himself to try to get his best moment this season with us. Of course, on Sunday we are finishing December and then starting January soon. The first match back he will play is against Chelsea.
"He has that challenge with me and himself, and with the club as well. I believe in him and hopefully we can get it."

Former Roma striker Daniel Fonseca has told struggling United star Joshua Zirkzee that he is the 'ideal' addition for the Serie A club. Speaking to Gazzetta dello Sport, the Uruguayan believes Roma should go for the attacker in January to boost their challenge for the title.

Fonseca said: "Gasperini deserves a big attacking signing in January. I keep hearing about Manchester United’s Zirkzee; he’d be perfect. With three points in Turin and a nice Christmas present, Roma could fight for the title right until the end."

The 24-year-old has made 10 appearances so far for United this season and scored just one goal against Crystal Palace. In recent weeks, the Dutch star has made more of an impact but managed just seven minutes in total against Wolves and Bournemouth.

Prior to this, he played two full games against Palace and Everton, plus 78 minutes against West Ham. However, the lack of goalscoring may tempt the young striker to find more consistent game time elsewhere.

body: Manchester United legend Ryan Giggs believes Ruben Amorim might discover a positive aspect in losing three crucial players to the Africa Cup of Nations. The Portuguese manager will be deprived of Bryan Mbeumo, Noussair Mazraoui and Amad Diallo until January as the trio depart to pursue international glory.

United are amongst the Premier League's most heavily African-represented teams. They share third place with several other clubs for the highest number of African players and also sit fourth for the percentage of minutes played by African internationals.

No boss wants to be without players at any point during the campaign, but the problem can become particularly acute during the packed festive schedule, when teams like United face three matches within nine days.
Yet absences can also present chances, enabling other squad members to step forward and prove their worth. Giggs reckons that, despite the upheaval, Amorim might gain from the circumstances.

"Sesko is now back, which helps. But it's definitely going to be a blow because Mbeumo has probably been the best player so far this season and looks like a real threat. Plays every game, has power, scores goals, and Amad can make things happen. So yeah, it's going to be tough.

"But with Sesko coming back, Cunha could drop back into where Mbeumo was playing. Amad will be difficult to replace, and I don't know how we're going to do it, whether we are going to change shape.

"I'm not too sure. But those two lads [Mbeumo and Amad] are definitely going to be missed. And I think United fans are just hoping that their countries don't go through the group stage, and we don't miss them for too long.
"The plus side is that Mason Mount has come back into the team. And that's a massive plus. You never know how good a player is until they're playing regularly.

"And now we're starting to see the Mason Mount that we've seen at Chelsea for a number of years. He's a good, clever player. All the coaches like him. When you're a manager, you want players you can trust, and he looks like someone you can really trust."

Benjamin Sesko has struggled to find his feet in the Premier League. The striker has netted just twice in the competition, with a knee problem that ruled him out for nearly a month disrupting his progress.
Now back to full fitness, he'll be determined to prove his worth.

Lisandro Martinez is also working his way back to peak condition following a cruciate ligament injury that sidelined him for nearly 300 days. The Argentine defender has faced numerous injury setbacks since arriving at Old Trafford and will be desperate to put those troubles behind him.
Mason Mount, similar to Martinez, has had his fair share of injury woes since joining United. Now back in form, the England international is showing promising signs as a regular starter under Amorim.

United are set to return to the pitch on Sunday, heading to the Midlands to take on high-flying Aston Villa. A win could potentially propel Amorim's team into the top four, depending on other match outcomes.

headline: Ruben Amorim issues new demand after losing THREE Man Utd stars for Aston Villa
body: Ruben Amorim has called on Manchester United’s squad to step up in the absence of their AFCON-bound stars. The Red Devils take on Aston Villa this weekend and are set to be without summer signings Bryan Mbeumo, Amad and Noussair Mazraoui.

The trio have linked up with the Cameroon, Ivory Coast, and Morocco squads, respectively, ahead of the African Cup of Nations. And while the United boss is aware of the impact their absences could have, he has called on the rest of the squad to step up during the tournament.
"We need to play a little bit different," Amorim said to MUTV ahead of Sunday’s trip to Villa Park. "We lost some one-against-one. We will see but we'll be ready for the game.
"It's perfect, it's not perfect as we don't have all the players, but we are ready. We have players that can solve the game for us, so are happy with that.
"Yes [we have lost Amad and Mbeumo] and also Nous," Ruben continued. "So Nous is also really important for us but, when one player is out, we have opportunities for other players.

"Last year, in some games, we managed to win, especially in Europe, without Amad. Bryan was not here, so we already have those moments of difficulty. So we are ready, more than ready, to cope with that."

And while United will be without Mbeumo, Amad and Mazraoui for the foreseeable future, one man who will provide Amorim with a considerable boost is Benjamin Sesko. The Slovenian is now back in contention having missed four matches with a knee injury, while he made a substitute appearance last time against Bournemouth.

"I think he is a different type of striker," Amorim said about the forward. "The only one in that part because Josh [Zirkzee] is more like a no.9 and 10 at the same time, a little bit like Cunha. Ben is a guy who likes to be in the box. He makes a lot of runs.
"Of course, if you look at him, you can feel that he has so much more to give. He is improving the physicality, he was one month without playing, but he is ready and he is going to help us."
United could potentially jump into the top four with victory against Aston Villa. They will follow up a trip to the Midlands with a Boxing Day clash with Newcastle at Old Trafford.

headline: MARSHALL: Ruben Amorim gives Bruno Fernandes injury update and makes Manchester United transfer statement
body: Ruben Amorim insists Manchester United won't rip up their January transfer plans despite losing captain Bruno Fernandes to a muscle injury against Aston Villa. Fernandes joined fellow midfielder Kobbie Mainoo on the injury list after he withdrew on the eve of the game.

Fernandes clutched his hamstring late in the first half at Villa Park and was forced off at the break, with Amorim confirming it was a soft tissue problem. Mainoo injured his calf in training on Saturday and couldn't be part of the squad.

Both midfielders are expected to miss the Boxing Day clash with Newcastle when United will find resources stretched to their limit. Casemiro will return to the side after serving a suspension against Aston Villa, but the out-of-form Manuel Ugarte is the only other fit senior central midfielder.

Amorim will look for solutions against the Magpies, but insisted he won't use the injuries as an excuse. Lisandro Martinez came on in midfield against Aston Villa and Jack Fletcher made his first-team debut from the bench.
“It’s a soft tissue, I think he’s going to lose some games, I don’t know for sure. Let’s see," Amorim said of Fernandes.
“I don’t know. I don’t want to talk about matters you can’t control. He is a guy who is always fit so he might recover quite well.
"I think Kobbie might be out [against Newcastle], Bruno is out, so we will see, we are going to find solutions, no excuses, we need to win the next game and we will try to win the next game."

United are reluctant to make a move for a short-term target in January, and Amorim has confirmed that he wants to stick to the long-term plan and wouldn't be asking director of football Jason Wilcox and chief executive Omar Berrada for a sticking plaster solution.
They are set to make a move for Antoine Semenyo when the window opens, with the attacker set to leave Bournemouth next month, but a move for a midfielder might have to wait until the summer.

"What we cannot do is to reach January and try to do everything in urgency and make mistakes," said Amorim. "And then here we go again with a lot of mistakes. I'm not going to get with Jason under Omar and I'm going to say we need a lot of players because we have a plan.

"If we have to suffer, the club comes first. Of course, we are in the moment that we need points, but we need to find solutions and we are going to continue with our plan. Of course, you can feel that in this moment we are going to struggle, but we'll see."

headline: MARSHALL: Ruben Amorim needs to change his tune on Manchester United transfers after nightmare 24 hours
body: When Ruben Amorim looks under his tree on Christmas Day, he is likely to be disappointed. The Manchester United head coach could do with finding a couple of midfielders wrapped up, and no pair of socks will make up for the disappointment of not finding Elliot Anderson or Adam Wharton ready to pop out of a box.

Amorim suggested on Friday that United were unlikely to sign a midfielder in January, but then he didn't expect to finish the game at Aston Villa with Lisandro Martinez and Jack Fletcher in the middle of the pitch. Christmas should be a time of giving, but it's been a costly week for Amorim and United.

Having seen Noussair Mazraoui, Amad and Bryan Mbeumo depart for the Africa Cup of Nations, he saw Kobbie Mainoo limp out of training on Saturday and Bruno Fernandes pull up at the end of the first half. Casemiro's suspension left the outmatched Manuel Ugarte as the only senior midfielder left standing.

Ugarte has fallen out of favour under Amorim, and at times at Villa Park, you could see why. His work in possession was particularly poor. He had to fill Fernandes' box-to-box role in the second half and it's difficult to make a case for a team stretched to that degree getting a result against the Premier League's in-form team.

That run of form is built on shaky foundations if you believe the data geeks, but Morgan Rogers is doing his best to condemn the boffins to the bin this season. He is making a habit of scoring stunners, so the solution is to make sure he can't shoot. Instead, Leny Yoro was so busy handing out gifts he should have been wearing a white beard.

He was too passive against Rogers and paid the price twice. It undid a lot of the good work that United put in at Villa Park. For the second game running, they created chances and looked like a threat going forward, but failed to win. It is now two wins in eight.

Villa came out of the blocks quickly, as you would expect of a team on a run of nine successive wins. Ayden Heaven twice had to block shots from Ollie Watkins, Senne Lammens made a save from John McGinn and Rogers reacted quickly to flick an Ian Maatsen drive towards goal in the six-yard box, only to see it squirm just wide.

United settled their rocking ship, however, and should have led by the midway point of the half. Benjamin Sesko found himself in on goal only to be denied by a sprawling save from Emiliano Martinez. A minute later, it was a clever pass from Matheus Cunha that sent Sesko in, but he took a heavy touch when trying to round Martinez, when he should have attempted to lift a first-time finish.

In a stodgy half, it was Rogers and Cunha who had looked like making something happen, and they delivered within minutes of each other. Rogers had nothing on when he picked up possession on the left touchline, but Yoro never got close to the Premier League's in-form player and let him drift into a shooting position, from where he picked his spot clinically.

Thankfully for United, Matty Cash was also in the Christmas spirit. He was caught napping by Patrick Dorgu, with the ball falling to Cunha. The Brazilian had plenty to do, but his unerring finish was measured to perfection.

The half-time loss of Fernandes was a hammer blow for United. The captain had stopped the game after clutching his hamstring, but continued until the break. He even had a goal-bound shot blocked by Ezri Konsa in that period, but couldn't continue. It meant Amorim had to raid his threadbare bench and the promotion of Martinez to midfield showed what he thought of the other options available to him.

Martinez settled into the game quickly, and United started the second half well, but were again undone by a moment of Rogers' magic. The finish was from a similar angle after the ball bounced clear to him, and again, Yoro was too cautious in trying to stop him. His two shots were worth a combined xG of 0.07 on the spreadsheet. Unfortunately for United, the game was being played on the pitch.

The consolation for Amorim was that his team was being beaten by stunners. So stretched were resources that the Portuguese called a truce with the academy, handing out two debuts, with Jack Fletcher and Shea Lacey coming off the bench.

Diogo Dalot forced Martinez into a save and Dorgu's follow-up was blocked by Cash. The recalled wing-back then stuck a cross on Cunha's head only for the Brazilian's effort to bounce wide. Lacey managed a shot on target from distance and Mount whipped a free-kick onto the roof of the net.
It was an afternoon when United could count themselves a little unlucky, but the results are flatlining again. Casemiro will return on Boxing Day. Who partners him is anyone's guess.

headline: MARSHALL: Why Kobbie Mainoo is missing from Manchester United squad vs Aston Villa
body: Kobbie Mainoo is absent from the Manchester United squad at Aston Villa after he picked up an injury in the final training session before the trip to Villa Park. The injury is described as a "small issue", but it is enough to rule the academy graduate out of a game he might have started.

Mainoo is yet to start a game in the Premier League this season and he is eyeing a loan move away from Old Trafford in January, but Ruben Amorim urged him to stay and fight for his place in his press conference ahead of the fixture against the league's in-form side.

Amorim had hinted he could play a back four against Villa, a formation that would have meant three midfielders and would have resulted in an expected promotion for Mainoo, 20, with Casemiro suspended after picking up a fifth booking of the season.
But his cruelly timed injury means he won't get to add to his 212 minutes of Premier League football so far this season. With Mainoo unavailable, Amorim has stuck by his 3-4-2-1 system.
United are short of options with Noussair Mazraoui, Amad and Bryan Mbeumo away at the Africa Cup of Nations. Mainoo has joined Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt on the treatment table.
Amorim was asked about Mainoo during his press conference and urged him to accept his current predicament and prove him wrong, hinting he could be in the side against Villa.

"Kobbie needs to fight for his job. I think that is not a bad thing to be on the bench of Manchester United when you are 20 years old," he said. "I remember Ronaldo was on the bench, Rooney was on the bench sometimes. Veron was not playing.

"So let's continue in trying to avoid the nonsense and the noise. I just want to help the team to win. To help Kobbie to be a better player. I'm not trying to say to Kobbie 'You are a big player here, let’s put him on the bench to show something.'
"No, no. What I’m saying is the opposite. I'm just not putting Kobe sometimes because I understand that this is not the right guy to start the game. Maybe the next game, Sunday he is going to start.

"If he plays well, is going to show everyone. 'This guy cannot take me for the team', and I will be so happy, so I don't care. I don't want to show nothing to anyone. I'm just saying that I'm trying to win games and to show to the players that if you do the things right, you will play no matter what the name."

headline: Man United injury latest and AFCON return dates: Ruben Amorim delivers Bruno Fernandes update
body: Bruno Fernandes will be out for a while, according to Ruben Amorim, after appearing to sustain a soft tissue injury during Manchester United's match against Aston Villa.

Lisandro Martinez replaced Fernandes at half-time and partnered Manuel Ugarte in central midfield. The club captain could not continue because of what looked like a hamstring issue after holding the back of his right leg.
Amorim also spoke about the club's wider injury situation. He said: "It is really strange.
"During this year, especially at this time, we have so many problems, but we have to cope with that." Fernandes becomes the sixth player currently unavailable for United.
MEN Sport reviews the complete list of United absentees and their expected return dates.

Ivory Coast called up Amad for the Africa Cup of Nations, which began on Sunday. The Elephants start their tournament against Mozambique on Christmas Eve, before facing Cameroon four days later and concluding the group stage on New Year's Eve versus Gabon.

Only eight teams go home before the knockout rounds, and as reigning champions, the Ivory Coast are among the favourites to win this edition. The round of 16 spans 3-5 January, with the quarter-finals taking place across the 9th and 10th.
Both semi-finals are on 14 January, with the final taking place four days later on 18 January. The third-place play-off is a day earlier than the final.

Ruben Amorim has said "it's going to be a while" before Bruno Fernandes is back because he believes the player's issue is a soft tissue injury. At least, it appears the problem will sideline him until January.

Fernandes must now also be a doubt for upcoming matches in the New Year against Arsenal and Manchester City. The former is United's final match in January, with six games to come between now and then.
The former is United's final match in January, with six games to come between now and then. Their spell without Fernandes starts with Newcastle United on Boxing Day.

Bryan Mbemuo, like Amad, is at the Africa Cup of Nations this winter, representing Cameroon. The Indomitable Lions are alongside the Ivory Coast in Group F, facing off on 28 December in their second group stage match.

Progression to the knockout stages is the expectation for both sides, with Cameroon doing so in each of the last four editions. If they make that five in a row, Mbeumo is likely to miss United's next four matches.
Reaching the quarter-finals will see the forward away around the FA Cup third-round weekend. Further progression from there may endanger his involvement in the Manchester derby.
A return in the New Year appears most likely for Harry Maguire. The defender has already missed a month after sustaining a hamstring injury in the 2-2 draw with Tottenham Hotspur.
United have already gone six consecutive matches without their former captain. That could soon increase to eight if he is not back before the end of December.

The visit to Leeds United on 4 January is a possible return date, with a trip to Burnley following three days later. Failing a comeback taking place in either of those fixtures, there is the FA Cup third round tie against Brighton & Hove Albion.

Ruben Amorim has said Kobbie Mainoo sustained an injury during training. He said: "After the final session, he went to the doctor, and he got something in his calf, so we are going to assess, but he is out of this game [against Aston Villa]. He is going to be fine in a few weeks, I don't know."

A few weeks means missing at least three and potentially as many as five matches. That also extends the player's absence into January, when the winter transfer window opens, meaning Mainoo could have already played his last game for United this season.

Boxing Day could come too early for Matthijs de Ligt, but a return in their final match of 2026 appears possible. The Netherlands international has dealt with a back injury this month, missing United's last four games.

After having to deploy Lisandro Martinez in midfield due to the absence of Bruno Fernandes, another defender's return would be welcome for Ruben Amorim. However, the team may well have to navigate one more match, against Newcastle United, before they can call on De Ligt once again.
Being back for trips to Burnley and Leeds United would be a big boost. The defender should also then be up to speed for the Manchester derby.

Africa Cup of Nations hosts Morocco kicked off the tournament with Noussair Mazraoui in their team on Sunday night. The defender assisted Brahim Diaz for the competition's opening goal after cutting the ball back for his teammate to fire home.
Morocco are next in action on Boxing Day against Mali, at the same time as his club play Newcastle. Their final group stage game is three days later.

Mazraoui missed Monday's match against Bournemouth after the Royal Moroccan Football Federation rejected a request from United to delay the player's departure. He could end up missing eight games in total as Morocco are the favourite to win the whole thing for the first time in 50 years.

headline: Gary Neville floored by shocking Man United moment vs Aston Villa - 'He's got no excuse'
body: Manchester United legend Gary Neville says Matheus Cunha had 'no excuse' to miss his second-half header from close range - an opportunity that would have drawn his team level for the second against Aston Villa.

Cunha had already levelled the scoring on the stroke of half-time, moments after Morgan Rogers had struck to hand Villa the advantage. United's failure to deal with their hosts then saw the Englishman restore the lead at 2-1 with 32 minutes left on the clock.

And again, shortly afterwards United's No.10 was presented with the chance to grab a second equaliser. With the freedom of the six-yard box, Cunha mishit a headed effort into the turf and it bounced the wrong side of the post.
"[It] had to be a goal. It's an absolutely brilliant pass from [Mason] Mount and a wonderful cross from [Patrick] Dorgu. On a plate.
"He's got no excuse, Cunha, he has to score."
The Brazilian looked devastated that he had not managed to convert the opportunity, lying face down on the turf before his teammates arrived to pick him up both literally and figuratively.

After his miss, United were still unable to muster a successful response in the time that remained and therefore lost the opportunity to move level on points with fourth-placed Chelsea following their slip-up at Newcastle United over 24 hours earlier.
Adding comment at full-time, Roy Keane added: "This is where football drives you mad.
"Absolutely brilliant delivery, as soon as it leaves his foot you're thinking [this is going to be a goal], and then there's no logic to it. We can't even explain it.
"We were saying here it is easier than a penalty. He's got five, six yards. Only the player maybe could explain it, whether he's lost concentration as it's coming onto his head?
"Sometimes for a player it is too easy. On target and it's a goal. Another big moment for United."

headline: MARSHALL: Amorim tells Kobbie Mainoo to do what Cristiano Ronaldo and Wayne Rooney did at Man United
body: Ruben Amorim has told Kobbie Mainoo to stay and "fight for his job" at Manchester United, telling the academy graduate to follow the example of Wayne Rooney and Cristiano Ronaldo, who both had spells on the bench but knuckled down to fight for their Old Trafford futures.

Mainoo is yet to start a Premier League game this season and could leave on loan next month, with Napoli at the head of a long list of suitors for his signature, but Amorim wants the academy graduate to stay and fight instead. Amorim took aim at the club legends telling Mainoo to leave on Friday and has now directed his message to the 20-year-old, who is frustrated at a lack of playing time at Old Trafford and is becoming a cause celebre among supporters, who are desperate to see one of their own playing more often.

"Kobbie needs to fight for his job. I think that is not a bad thing to be on the bench of Manchester United when you are 20 years old," said Amorim. "I remember Ronaldo was on the bench, Rooney was on the bench sometimes. [Juan Sebastian] Veron was not playing. I remember all the history of Manchester United and nobody. So let's continue in trying to avoid the nonsense and the noise. I just want to help the team win. To help Kobbie to be a better player."

Amorim insisted he wasn't using Mainoo to make a point that big players must earn their stripes at Old Trafford and accept a spell on the bench, but that he must prove the head coach wrong when he gets a chance. Mainoo could earn a first league start of the season at Aston Villa on Sunday, with Amorim confirming he is considering a switch to a back four, which could offer Mainoo a route into the team as one of three midfielders.

If he does get the chance, then Amorim urged the young midfielder to use his anger as fuel to show everyone what he can do. "I’m not trying to say to Kobbie, 'You are a big player here, let’s put him on the bench to show something'," he said.

"No, no. What I’m saying is the opposite. I'm just not putting Kobbie sometimes because I understand that this is not the right guy to start the game. Maybe the next game, on Sunday, he is going to start.

"If he plays well, he's going to show everyone. 'This guy cannot take me from the team', and I will be so happy, so I don't care. I don't want to show nothing to anyone. I'm just saying that I'm trying to win games and to show to the players that if you do the things right, you will play no matter what the name."

A week ago Amorim told Mainoo to come and see him if he wanted a loan move in January. That didn't happen and Mainoo's future took another turn on Monday, when half-brother Jordan wore a t-shirt saying 'Free Kobbie Mainoo' to the game against Bournemouth.
"He’s a shy boy, but it's not his responsibility. He's responsible for his acts and his act was to play well in the last game, I'm just focused on that," said Amorim.

"I had the situation in Sporting (Lisbon) that my brother wrote something on the internet, and I have to answer for that. My explanation is that he has his life, he has his opinion, and it's nothing to do with me. So I will do the same with Kobbie."

headline: MARSHALL: Amorim drops Antoine Semenyo hint as Manchester United plan January transfer raid
body: Manchester United will make a move for Bournemouth forward Antoine Semenyo next month, with Ruben Amorim confirming the club will only consider transfers that make long-term sense. Semenyo has a £65million release clause in his Bournemouth contract, which is only active for part of January, to give the Cherries enough time to replace their main man.

In addition to United, Manchester City, Liverpool, and Tottenham are also interested in signing the 25-year-old. Amorim labelled Semenyo a "special player" before United's 4-4 draw with Bournemouth on Monday and saw first hand how dangerous he can be, with the Ghana international netting his seventh goal of the season.

He is a versatile forward and could be used at wing-back if United land their man, although they will face fierce competition to do so next month. United have recently lost three players to the Africa Cup of Nations, but Amorim confirmed that there will be short-term moves next month and hinted that any deal could be in a position that isn't necessarily the top priority.
While United are planning a midfield rebuild for 2026, they are bringing a move for Semenyo forward because of the expectation he will leave Bournemouth in January.

"The only thing that we know is that we only would try to bring players that we think is going to be the future," said Amorim. "It's not going to be to save something in this moment, to cope with the losses of three players for AFCON.

"It’s not going to be like that, even if we try to bring one player, maybe it's not the position that we need more. We will try to bring now – and in the end of the season – players that are perfect for our future.
"So I don't know what is going to happen, but it's possible that we can do something."

headline: Three ways Man United can line up vs Aston Villa without Casemiro and absent trio
body: Manchester United's starting line-up vs Aston Villa on Sunday will be a lot different to the side which drew 4-4 with Bournemouth on Monday night. Noussair Mazraoui was already missing from that team as he linked up with his Morocco teammates ahead of the Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON).

However, he will be joined on the absentee list by Amad and Bryan Mbeumo. They were given special allowance by their national teams to play against the Cherries but will not be available for selection when the team travel to Villa on Sunday. But if that was not enough for Ruben Amorim, there is another matter to contend with.

United shall also be without the services of Casemiro in the West Midlands this weekend. The Brazilian picked up his fifth booking of the campaign, not including the two he received against Chelsea, on Monday night and will therefore be suspended for one game.

His absence leaves a hole in the midfield which will need to be plugged by the Reds. With this in mind, MEN Sport has taken a look at three ways United could choose to line-up in the absence of Casemiro.

United could simply decide to make a straight swap with Casemiro dropping out for Manuel Ugarte. Many predicted the Uruguayan would have a bigger role at Old Trafford once Amorim arrived considering their history together at Sporting.

Instead, Ugarte has failed to push on and has dropped behind Casemiro in the pecking order. This would have been inconceivable at one stage considering the Brazilian was so far off the pace in the Premier League last season.
But in 2025/26, Casemiro remains the best option in defensive midfielder and there is little chance his suspension will damage his chances of returning to the Boxing Day squad vs Newcastle.

There is a lot of talk about whether United are ready to play with four at the back considering the number of absentees - especially against Villa. One option available to Amorim is to return to a 4-3-3 formation which the Reds, and this group of players, have used previously.

Amorim has stated Kobbie Mainoo could feature more in such a system. Should this be the case, Amorim could kill two birds with one stone and ease the tension surrounding the academy graduate's playing time this season while also finding a way around the Casemiro headache.
Without Casemiro, there would still be a place for Ugarte in this formation and both he and Mainoo would benefit from three players in that midfield.

The wildcard option for United would depend entirely on whether or not Amorim is ready to change his mind entirely. Lisandro Martinez has played as a defensive midfielder before - for Ajax when Erik ten Hag was struggling for numbers in that position.

Amorim stated recently he did not see Martinez as a midfielder as he is not taking on that workload currently. Since his long-term injury, the Argentine has been focusing on being a defender but if Ugarte is not seen as a viable option, Martinez could be utilised there.

He could play as the anchor just ahead of the centre-backs which would once again allow Mainoo an opportunity to impress. However, it seems obvious this is a long shot considering Amorim's recent comments on Martinez.

headline: Gary Neville spots Ruben Amorim breaking his golden rule at Man United
body: Ex-Manchester United defender Gary Neville has had his say on discussions surrounding a change of formation in the side's 4-4 draw with AFC Bournemouth at Old Trafford on Monday night.
It came as a surprise to supporters when watching the game, as the starting line-up appeared to point towards a back five, but the side shuffled into more of a four during the match.

That is despite head coach Ruben Amorim being insistent over the first year or so of his tenure that he would not change, having previously made his stance clear in the media over a move from the five to a four.
He said: "No one. Not even the Pope will change [his tactics]. This is my job. This is my responsibility. This is my life. So, I will not change that."
Those were quotes that Neville reflected on in the latest recording of the Stick To Football podcast, before having his say on the changes that United made in the game.
He said: "So, basically, he's saying that he's never going to change the system. On Monday night, that's the average positions, that's the graphic. On Monday night, the average position.

"I mean, look, my eyes, to be fair, at times thought they were deceiving me because I couldn't quite work out what he was doing. It was in no doubt at the end, but it was no doubt he was in 4-2-4 at the end, but he was also during the game; something was different on Monday night.
"Has he changed it...? The last 20 minutes he was definitely 4-4-2, 4-2-4, but in the first part of the game, there was something definitely different that had been identified earlier in the week.

"Apparently, United are a bit annoyed, basically it's leaked out that he's gonna change to a 4-4-2 or a 4-3-3. He was emphatic about not changing, and we've all asked for him to change and be agile. Where are we now in respect to, there's no doubt on Monday he changed."
